parts.text:
Figure 1 shows the proportion of electricity generated by different renewable energy resources in the UK in 2020.

Calculate the percentage of electricity generated using hydroelectric power.

A remote village in the UK uses a hydroelectric generator to provide electricity.

The mass of water that passes through the hydroelectric generator each day is $2\,500\,000\,\text{kg}$. The change in vertical height of the water is $15.0\,\text{m}$. Gravitational field strength $= 9.8\,\text{N/kg}$.

Calculate the decrease in gravitational potential energy of the water using $E_p = mgh$.
Write down the equation which links energy ($E$), power ($P$) and time ($t$).
markScheme: 1 mark: $E = P\times t$ (or energy = power × time)

parts.text:
The hydroelectric generator transfers electrical power of $3000\,\text{W}$ to the village.

Calculate the energy transferred to the village in 60 minutes.
markScheme: 1 mark: $E = 10\,800\,000\,\text{J}$ (allow $1.08\times 10^7\,\text{J}$; allow consistent answer if time not converted)

parts.text:
Figure 2 shows how the power output of the hydroelectric generator varied during one year.

Explain one reason why the power output varied.
markScheme: 1 mark: The level/flow of water in the river varies (or amount of rainfall varies)
1 mark: It is lower in summer months / depends on season (MP2 depends on MP1)

parts.text:
The diagram shows how the National Grid connects power stations to consumers.

Name the parts of the National Grid labelled K, L and M.
markScheme: 1 mark: L = transmission cables (allow power cables)
1 mark: M = step-down transformer (allow 1 mark if K and M labelled transformer but step-up/step-down incorrect)

parts.text:
Figure 1 shows how the percentage of electricity generated by gas-fired power stations changed in the UK over 5 years.

Calculate how many times greater the percentage of electricity generated by gas-fired power stations was in 2018 than in 2014.
Explain one environmental effect of generating electricity using a gas-fired power station.
markScheme: 1 mark: Burning gas releases carbon dioxide
1 mark: Carbon dioxide causes global warming / greenhouse effect / climate change

parts.text:
What is a renewable energy resource?

Tick (✓) one box.

Options:
A) An energy resource that can be burned
B) An energy resource that can be recycled
C) An energy resource that can be replenished quickly
D) An energy resource that can be reused
markScheme: 1 mark: C - An energy resource that can be replenished quickly

parts.text:
Figure 2 shows the power output of an offshore wind farm compared with a wind farm on land for a 24-hour period.

Give two advantages of the offshore wind farm compared with the wind farm on land. Use information from Figure 2.
markScheme: 1 mark: Higher power output / more electricity generated
1 mark: Lower variation / more constant power output

parts.text: Write down the equation which links density ($\rho$), mass ($m$) and volume ($V$).

The reservoir stores $6\,500\,000\,\text{m}^3$ of water. The density of the water is $998\,\text{kg/m}^3$.

Calculate the mass of water in the reservoir. Give your answer in standard form.
Write down the equation which links energy transferred ($E$), power ($P$) and time ($t$).
markScheme: 1 mark: $E = Pt$ (or energy transferred = power × time)

parts.text:
The electrical generators can provide $1.5\times 10^9\,\text{W}$ of power for a maximum of 5 hours.

Calculate the maximum energy that can be transferred by the electrical generators.

The graph shows how the UK demand for electricity increases and decreases during one day.

The hydroelectric power station can provide $1.5\times 10^9\,\text{W}$ of power for a maximum of 5 hours.

Give two reasons why this hydroelectric power station is not able to meet the increase in demand shown between 04:00 and 16:00 on the graph.
markScheme: 1 mark: The increase/variation in demand is greater than $1.5\times 10^9\,\text{W}$ (power output)
1 mark: Demand remains high for longer than 5 hours (04:00 to 16:00 is 12 hours)

parts.text:
Nuclear fusion is the joining together of ___.

During nuclear fusion the total mass of the particles ___.

Electricity is used to increase the temperature of $4.0\,\text{g}$ of deuterium by $50\,000\,000^{\circ}\,\mathrm{C}$. Specific heat capacity of deuterium $= 5200\,\text{J/kg}^{\circ}\,\mathrm{C}$.

Calculate the energy needed to increase the temperature of the deuterium by $50\,000\,000^{\circ}\,\mathrm{C}$.

The idea of obtaining power from nuclear fusion was investigated using models. The models were tested before starting to build the first commercial nuclear fusion power station.

Suggest two reasons why models were tested.
markScheme: 2 marks: Any two from: make sure process is possible; develop understanding; make adaptations; assess efficiency; make predictions; assess safety risks; assess environmental impact; lower setup cost for small-scale experiments.

parts.text:
Generating electricity using nuclear fusion will have fewer environmental effects than generating electricity using fossil fuels.

Explain one environmental effect of generating electricity using fossil fuels.
markScheme: 1 mark: Fossil fuels release carbon dioxide / greenhouse gases (or particulates / sulfur dioxide / nitrogen oxides)
1 mark: Causes global warming / climate change (or global dimming / breathing problems / acid rain, consistent with MP1)

questions.subtopic: Fossil fuels, climate change and thermistors
questions.title: Electricity generation, climate change and thermistors

parts.text:
Figure 1 shows how much electricity was generated using coal-fired and gas-fired power stations in January for 5 years in the UK.

Determine the percentage increase in electricity generated using gas-fired power stations from 2014 to 2018.
Give two environmental advantages of using a gas-fired power station to generate electricity compared with using a coal-fired power station.
markScheme: 2 marks: Any two from: no sulfur dioxide (no acid rain); no particulates (no global dimming); less carbon dioxide per kg fuel (less global warming/climate change); no solid waste; gas mining less destructive than coal mining.

parts.text:
Figure 2 shows how the mean sea surface temperature changed between 1988 and 2016.

A student does not believe that climate change is occurring. Explain how the data in Figure 2 suggests the student is wrong.
markScheme: 1 mark: Mean sea surface temperature shows a (steady) increase over time
1 mark: Support with data between two dates at least 10 years apart (e.g. 16.45°C to 16.96°C)

parts.text:
Figure 3 shows how the resistance of four different thermistors A, B, C and D varies with temperature.

Which of the four thermistors would be the most suitable to measure the surface temperature of the sea? Tick (✓) one box (A, B, C or D). Explain your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: Because the change in resistance is greatest / gradient highest / most sensitive
1 mark: In the relevant temperature range (about 0 to 25°C / around 16–17°C)
